Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Ana Elisa Lambert  Both equally
Instructor: Ana Elisa Lambert  Ana was incredibly helpful and a joy to have in class.
Instructor: Ana Elisa Lambert  Ana Lambert
Instructor: Ana Elisa Lambert  Ana was great. She was responsive when issues arose with the class and always happy and helpful.
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess was always helpful and very responsive to students and their questions.
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Both equally

Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jessica was a phenomenal TA. She was very responsive to student concerns and also did a great job (along with Ana) organizing the course guests that appeared throughout the semester.

Instructor: Jessica Leung  Honestly, I can't say enough about Jessica and her work this semester. While I had concerns regarding the structure and content of the course this semester, none of this is a reflection on Jessica. She has a clear passion for the issues we were exploring this semester that goes beyond just a cursory understanding of the content. Her dedication to bringing in speakers from across the country enriched our classroom dialogue and truly made this a worthwhile course. I would be thrilled to have Jessica as a TA again during my time at Yale.
Instructor: Jessica Leung  I asked Jessica questions occasionally and she was always very helpful and friendly, but I spoke with Julie about the course the most.
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jessica Leung

Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess was also great. She was also responsive, helpful, and she and Ana were both pivotal to the smooth running of the course, especially with all the guest speakers throughout the course.
Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess is amazing. It is very clear that she put an incredible amount of effort into making this class work, and I value her so much

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jessica Leung  Jess was very organized and very responsive to any requests. She also was able to help students with the assignments and coordinated most of the guest speakers that came to our class.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 13 Julie and Paul were such great instructors. They challenged my thinking, but they were also very receptive to student concerns or questions. They made themselves very available to meet and talk with students.
Q12- I typically worked with Julie when I had any questions about assignments or the class overall so I don't have a good sense of how responsive Paul was or was not to students.

I had high hopes for this class, and while there were some true bright spots during the course of the semester, there were also some missteps. I can say that it was clear both Professor Anastas and Zimmerman worked incredibly hard in making this a unique learning experience - which it was. I think the model and structure of this class is one that could inform how other FES courses are developed. That said, I did feel like the best part of the course came early on as we walked through the science and infrastructure relating to the Flint crisis. It is clear that both Julie and Paul are incredible scientists and engineers whose knowledge in these areas seem to have no bounds. Learning from them was really a gift for someone like myself who has little background in these areas. Unfortunately, once the subject matter shifted to more nuanced issues relating to social justice, race relations and urban decline it did feel like both professors were well outside of their comfort zone. This isn't to say that they didn't put in the hard work to learn and grow alongside students - in fact, they did just that. But I would suggest that moving forward the professors look to their students who have worked in these fields (or come in with more than just a 101 understanding of the root issues at play) for more guidance in shaping the discussion. I will say I think this had more to do with the subject matter than the professors themselves. In past years, I believe this course has looked at crises that stem more from infrastructure mishaps than systemic power imbalances within our country. Flint is a unique case in this way. While past courses would likely have attracted a more select group of students interested in water systems and resource management, this semester brought in a much more diverse group of students with varying backgrounds and strengths. For instance, most students I spoke with were well aware that the issues facing Flint were not solely rooted in just the antiquated piping of the city - it was why we were looking to take the course in the first place. It often felt like this fact was lost on our professors who may have been operating under the pretenses of past Science to Solutions courses.

This course was terrific. It was great to practice addressing such a thorny environmental problem and making sense of knowledge gained in a messy way throughout the semester. I am confident the tools we learned in systems thinking and multi-criteria analysis will be invaluable going forward.

3. The consecutive nature of the briefs was overwhelming 4. The beginning of the class, which involved building our toolkits, was too slow, while the speaker series/policy brief/final presentation section felt very rushed.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Guest speakers were amazing I loved the format and structure of the course
The systems thinking/problem statement components, the guest speakers

This was probably one of the most useful classes I have ever taken in my life. It provided concepts and tools that are applicable and needed in the real world and opened alot of students up to a new way of thinking. Overall, it helped us understand the Flint crisis from several perspectives that many of us were lacking to some extent.
The interdisciplinary approach and to learn how to write briefing papers
Applying systems thinking. Good guest speakers.

This is largely a comment on FES, and became apparent due to the strengths of this course. The only people of color and women guests that I heard from in classes all semester were in Science to Solutions. This is an unfortunate fact, as I truly believe there are many stories within environmentalism that should be shared from many backgrounds and cultures. I found this course to be challenging, but realistic. While I learned a lot and had to stretch myself in many instances to meet the expectations of my peers and instructors, I felt supported all the way.

The ability to look at and examine an ongoing, dynamic issue facing a community in real time. I truly believe this model of learning and systems thinking could be transformative for FES and our staff/student development moving forward. Additionally, learning from Julie and Paul - as well as the many speakers and guests they brought in - was fantastic.

Several of the outside speakers were outstanding and learning how to interact with an expert in a fixed amount of time in order to write a policy brief is an incredibly useful skill. I also loved working with my group on the final project.

Paul and Julie are incredible professors. The speakers were amazing and I'm so impressed we had all of them. The briefing papers and final paper were great exercises but should've been spaced out more.

It provided a variety of viewpoints regarding the issue through the guest speakers, as opposed to the one or two viewpoints often provided in courses. It taught systems thinking, which was a really valuable tool in looking forward and at environmental problems holistically.

The guest speakers were phenomenal and the causal loop tools were useful. The course was very timely. Systems thinking, and the inclusion of environmental justice and communication, should be included in all FES courses.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I wish it could be longer! It would have been nice to get the community perspective earlier in the semester
The grading on briefings felt incredibly random - as if there was no correlation between effort and grade. More clarity re: what criteria are used to evaluate grades would be really helpful!

It was alot of work and at times, very fast paced. I think there was a misunderstanding of how much time and work was needed for each assignment. The order of the course could also be improved since we learned about systems thinking in the very beginning but then didn't use it until the very end of the semester.
It needs more systems thinking theory back up: Some Maturana, Meadows, Luhmann.
Heavy course load.

The timing of the course is one of the areas needing the most improvement. I waited all semester to hear from Flint residents and activists, and they were the last two speakers of the semester. I believe more emphasis should be made on requesting the participation of activists and citizens who are directly engaged in these challenges, rather than academics and researchers. The briefing papers were helpful writing exercises, but oftentimes felt repetitive and we did not receive clear expectations for the assignments, so I truly believe my performance plateaued. I believe there should be another assignment that addresses these core issue areas during the semester (perhaps replacing a paper with an individual presentation). Our final presentation happened very late in the semester and I believe the writing exercise was too long and disjointed from our initial course perspective on writing. We spent the entire semester working to communicate issues in the most concise and specific manner, and worked to create a shared document with 20, single-spaced spaces. The expectations were not clearly communicated, and our group struggled as a result. Finally, I believe having the final presentation earlier in the semester would have kept my personal motivation going, as I became a bit discouraged by the end of the semester. It would have been great to present our best ideas and return to the drawing board to refine them and develop more specific proposals for solutions.

While the guest speakers were wonderful, many of them clearly needed to have their presentations edited down to allow for Q&A or discussion. It might be better to either add an additional class time just for speakers, or to cut down on the number of speakers. I also would recommend spending a bit more time at the beginning of the course to lay the foundation for the specifics of the issue. Many of my colleagues were coming from outside the United States, so Flint was not as familiar to them at the start. The amount of time to develop our final policy recommendations was far too short, in my opinion. I would have loved more time to really consider outside case studies or potential policy solutions in my submission, but given the time - and the group structure of the project, that wasn't an option. I would also recommend that the final presentation class seemed unnecessary and didn't add anything to our learning or understanding of the issue.

If possible, I think it would be helpful to prep the speakers a bit more on our baseline knowledge before they develop the content they'd like to present, and screen the questions we'd like to ask as a group beforehand to get the most out of the session time. I also felt that we were missing class time on public economics and urban development.
Structure: there should be one class on what happened, then start the speakers/briefing papers, and then do the MCA, CLD, etc at the end.

The course organization could have been better. For example, we learned about causal loop diagrams and multi-criteria decision analyses, which were great and useful, but we didn't use them until much later in the course. The gap between learning and using made it more difficult to grasp the subjects immediately.

This course attempted to tackle a huge topic, and the effort was valiant. While I am glad that this class exists, I cannot say that I enjoyed it. This is largely because the sociological conditions and implications of this case study did not get the nuanced analysis that it warranted. This is not necessarily the fault of the professors, but rather speaks to a larger problem FES has with procuring professors who specialize in environmental humanities. While it was interesting to witness the professors learning more about topics such as environmental justice as the class was learning, it was frustrating to not achieve any depth in those topics.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Paul and Julie come from such impressive government backgrounds. Their ability to connect science to policy really demonstrates the goal for a number of FES students.

One of the few classes at FES that is truly interdisciplinary. I think there should be more systems thinking/interdisciplinary classes like this at FES because that is really what the MEM degree is about. This class teaches important interdisciplinary problem solving skills.

This is truly an interdisciplinary course that brings in so many areas of study relevant to FES and its students. I think more than any course I took this semester, the takeaways from this class could be wildly different depending on the student, which I believe is a real benefit to our learning environment.
I am very interested in policy analysis and the skills we learned in applying systems thinking and multi-criteria analysis to make policy recommendations will be very useful for me.
This class is essential for me, as I hope to work with urban water systems

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was interested in Flint, and it seemed like a very unique course compared to the others being offered this semester.

I was interested in learning about Flint and how someone in a position of authority would be able to prevent the crisis in another city. Overall, I am also interested in water systems management and this seemed like the best case study to learn from.
I hope to apply the systems thinking skills to my career.
I was interested in working on a concrete environmental case study to test the skills I already have and identify gaps in my knowledge that I should fill in the rest of my time at FES.

I took this course because it was the hands-on application of tools learned to an immediate problem to come up with solutions and learn how to look at the system as a whole. These are skills other courses weren't advertising or teaching. As well, the course provided viewpoints from a diverse range of people from activists to professors to politicians, and no other course I took provided such a breadth of personal knowledge like this one did.
It is a prerequisite for other course I hope to take, and I was interested in learning more about Flint.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Absolutely! This was my favorite class of the semester!
Not that much, i missed more system thinking theory and more depth in some contents.

Yes- I would have enjoyed more application of the systems thinking tools we learned such as the multi-criteria analysis and the causal loop diagram. However, there does not seem to be much time in the class since it is filled with other great components of the class. I would recommend a separate systems thinking class.

Yes, although I think I'd had a vision that we would learn more chemistry during the course (which was just a misunderstanding on my part of how this type of course is structured). We did have some class time dedicated to aquatic chemistry which was great.
Yes, very much so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Really helpful to have so many class periods dedicated just to group work. Not really disadvantages, just the normal challenges that come with group projects.

For so many reasons, I really hate group work at FES. I don't think they are an accurate representation of group work in a professional setting. I struggled with my group - people with different exam schedules didn't meet certain internal deadlines, and trying to cohesively write a 20 page paper in 3 weeks is somewhat unrealistic considering the varying workloads and schedules of other students.

It was helpful to bring together everyone's ideas but group work at the end of the semester is always stressful and there never seems to be enough time. Plus, as much as they tried to create really ideal teams, I think some ended up much more unbalanced than others.

We need more acceptance of differences in opinion, this is not only a US-Centric university. There is diversity and diverse opinions. Recommended to make this a verbal clear understanding ahead of class with other class mates.

My group worked well together. In the class, we were assigned groups for our final project based on a questionnaire we did and there was also an evaluation of your team members to ensure accountability.

Advantages: Positive challenging experience. I don't believe I have ever worked in a group that was so focused on collaboration. Disadvantages: I had a very different working style than my classmates and struggled to manage the expectations of my peers. I also believe there was a lack of trust and emphasis on micromanaging work rather than working independently, which was frustrating for me. I would recommend a more comprehensive group matching process, as I do not believe I was a good fit for my group, although we did end up with a great final product.
The group work in this course didn't seem to work since the nature of the project didn't lend itself to an equitable group work dynamic.

Working in a group on the final project was a terrific experience for me. I learned so much from the other gals in my group and just the iterative process of coming up with ideas and evaluating them as a group was both fascinating and a lot of fun. I'm not sure what the process was for creating the groups but mine had a wonderful team dynamic.
The group work at the end was far too rushed. I do not think we had adequate time to really work as a group, rather we were individuals who compiled information to turn in one product.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: take it! be prepared to work hard and be challengedd.

The course is alot of work but you will come out with alot of new knowledge and a better perspective on science, government, environmental justice, law, and public policy. Also, get help early and often from the teaching team if you are unclear on the concepts.
To pay attention to the briefing papers
Great course! Learn a lot and can apply skills learned to other environmental problems.This course is a lot of work so plan accordingly with your other courses.

Start your research on the topic asap before the policy briefs even begin to be assigned. Reach out to the professors and the teaching assistants early as well - they are all brilliant, passionate, approachable, and incredibly helpful.
Take it. It is a valuable course for looking at issues holistically instead of narrowly.
